title: Complete Bearded Dragon Lighting Guide: UVB & Full-Spectrum Setup
description: Learn how to set up proper UVB and full-spectrum lighting for your bearded dragon, including bulb recommendations, placement distances, and the importance of bright daylight.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Essential Lighting Requirements for Bearded Dragons
content.content: Proper lighting is critical for bearded dragon health and longevity. This guide provides evidence-based recommendations for UVB exposure, full-spectrum illumination, and thermal regulation based on their natural Australian habitat.

Ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation enables bearded dragons to photosynthesize vitamin D3, which regulates calcium metabolism. Inadequate UVB exposure leads to metabolic bone disease (MBD) regardless of dietary calcium supplementation.

content.text: UVB Requirements:

content.content: UVB lighting is non-negotiable for bearded dragon health. Dietary vitamin D3 supplementation cannot substitute for natural photosynthesis and will not prevent metabolic bone disease.
Linear T5 high-output fluorescent bulbs provide optimal UVB output and coverage for adult bearded dragon enclosures (minimum 4×2×2 feet):

content.text: Recommended UVB Bulbs:

content.content: Compact/coil UVB bulbs are not recommended. They provide inadequate coverage and have shorter lifespans (6 months vs 12 months for T5 HO linear bulbs).
UVB intensity follows inverse square law—output decreases exponentially with distance. Proper positioning is critical for achieving therapeutic UVI levels while avoiding photodamage.

content.text: Mounting Distance Guidelines:

content.content: Verification Recommended: Use a Solarmeter 6.5 UVI meter to confirm target UVI at basking level. Distance requirements vary by fixture design and bulb age.

High-intensity visible light (6500K color temperature) is essential for behavioral health and circadian regulation. UVB alone does not provide sufficient illumination for optimal diurnal activity patterns.
Critical Distinction: Full-spectrum lighting provides bright white illumination for activity and behavior. UVB provides metabolically active radiation. Both are required.

content.text: Full-Spectrum Lighting Options:

content.content: Consistent light cycles regulate circadian rhythms, appetite, and seasonal breeding behaviors. Use programmable timers to maintain accurate schedules:

content.text: Lighting Schedule by Season:

content.content: Use digital timers with battery backup to maintain schedules during power outages. Inconsistent lighting can disrupt appetite and behavior patterns.
UVB output degrades over time independent of visible brightness. Timely replacement prevents subclinical UV deficiency and metabolic complications:

content.text: Bulb Replacement Schedule:

content.content: Best Practice: Label bulbs with installation date using permanent marker. Set calendar reminders 2 weeks before replacement due date to order new bulbs in advance.
